content:
Write a Java program that uses AWS Lambda to resize images uploaded to an S3 bucket. When an image is uploaded, trigger a Lambda function to create a thumbnail version of the image and save it back to the same S3 bucket.
PLAINFORMAT

Alright, I've got this task to create a Java program that uses AWS Lambda to resize images uploaded to an S3 bucket. So, whenever someone uploads an image to the S3 bucket, I need to automatically create a thumbnail version of that image and save it back to the same bucket. Sounds interesting!

First, I need to understand the components involved here. There's AWS Lambda, which is a serverless computing service provided by AWS. It allows you to run code in response to events without provisioning or managing servers. Then there's Amazon S3, which is a object storage service. So, when an image is uploaded to an S3 bucket, it should trigger a Lambda function that resizes the image.

I need to set this up using Java. I'm familiar with Java, but I'm not too sure about integrating it with AWS Lambda and S3. I think I need to write a Lambda function in Java that gets triggered by an S3 event, specifically when an object (image) is uploaded.

Let me start by setting up an AWS Lambda function in Java. I believe I need to create a handler class that implements the RequestHandler interface or something similar. The handler will receive events in the form of S3Object events, I think.

First, I need to set up my development environment. I should use AWS SDK for Java to interact with S3 and Lambda. Maybe I can use Maven to manage dependencies.

Let me sketch a rough plan:

1. Set up a Maven project with AWS SDK dependencies.

2. Create a Lambda handler class that implements RequestHandler<S3Event, Void>.

3. In the handler method, retrieve the uploaded image from S3.

4. Resize the image to create a thumbnail.

5. Upload the thumbnail back to the same S3 bucket.

6. Set up an S3 bucket to trigger the Lambda function on object upload.

Alright, step 1: Set up a Maven project.

I'll create a new Maven project and add the necessary dependencies. I need the AWS SDK for S3 and Lambda.

In my pom.xml, I'll add dependencies for aws-sdk-s3 and aws-lambda-java-core.

Wait, actually, for Lambda development in Java, there's a specific set of dependencies. Let me look that up.

Yes, for Lambda, I need to include aws-lambda-java-core and aws-lambda-java-events. Also, since I'm dealing with S3, I need aws-java-sdk-s3.

So, my pom.xml will look something like this:

```xml

<dependencies>

    <dependency>

        <groupId>com.amazonaws</groupId>

        <artifactId>aws-lambda-java-core</artifactId>

        <version>1.2.1</version>

    </dependency>

    <dependency>

        <groupId>com.amazonaws</groupId>

        <artifactId>aws-lambda-java-events</artifactId>

        <version>3.10.0</version>

    </dependency>

    <dependency>

        <groupId>com.amazonaws</groupId>

        <artifactId>aws-java-sdk-s3</artifactId>

        <version>1.12.102</version>

    </dependency>

</dependencies>

```

Okay, now that I have my dependencies set up, I can proceed to write the Lambda handler.

Step 2: Create the Lambda handler class.

I need to create a class that implements RequestHandler<S3Event, Void>. The S3Event is provided by aws-lambda-java-events.

Here's a basic structure:

```java

import com.amazonaws.services.lambda.runtime.Context;

import com.amazonaws.services.lambda.runtime.RequestHandler;

import com.amazonaws.services.lambda.runtime.events.S3Event;

import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;

import java.io.ByteArrayInputStream;

import java.io.ByteArrayOutputStream;

import java.io.IOException;

import javax.imageio.ImageIO;

import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3;

import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3ClientBuilder;

import com.amazonaws.services.s3.model.GetObjectRequest;

import com.amazonaws.services.s3.model.ObjectMetadata;

import com.amazonaws.services.s3.model.PutObjectRequest;

public class ImageResizerHandler implements RequestHandler<S3Event, Void> {

    @Override

    public Void handleRequest(S3Event input, Context context) {

        // Handle the event

        return null;

    }

}

```

Alright, now I need to handle the S3 event. The S3Event contains records of the objects that were uploaded. I need to iterate through these records, get the bucket name and object key, then retrieve the image from S3, resize it, and put it back.

First, I need to create an AmazonS3 client to interact with S3.

I can do this using AmazonS3ClientBuilder:

```java

AmazonS3 s3Client = AmazonS3ClientBuilder.defaultClient();

```

Then, for each record in the S3Event, I can get the bucket name and object key:

```java

for (S3EventNotification.S3EventNotificationRecord record : input.getRecords()) {

    String bucketName = record.getS3().getBucket().getName();

    String objectKey = record.getS3().getObject().getKey();

}

```

## Final Solution
To achieve the goal of resizing images uploaded to an S3 bucket using an AWS Lambda function in Java, follow these steps:

### 1. Set Up the Project

First, create a new Maven project and set up the necessary dependencies in your `pom.xml` file:

```xml
<dependencies>
    <dependency>
        <groupId>com.amazonaws</groupId>
        <artifactId>aws-lambda-java-core</artifactId>
        <version>1.2.1</version>
    </dependency>
    <dependency>
        <groupId>com.amazonaws</groupId>
        <artifactId>aws-lambda-java-events</artifactId>
        <version>3.10.0</version>
    </dependency>
    <dependency>
        <groupId>com.amazonaws</groupId>
        <artifactId>aws-java-sdk-s3</artifactId>
        <version>1.12.102</version>
    </dependency>
    <dependency>
        <groupId>javax.imageio</groupId>
        <artifactId>imageio</artifactId>
        <version>1.0.0</version>
    </dependency>
</dependencies>
```

### 2. Create the Lambda Handler

Create a Lambda handler class that implements `RequestHandler<S3Event, Void>`. This handler will process events triggered by uploads to the S3 bucket.

```java
package com.example;

import com.amazonaws.services.lambda.runtime.Context;
import com.amazonaws.services.lambda.runtime.RequestHandler;
import com.amazonaws.services.lambda.runtime.events.S3Event;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3ClientBuilder;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.model.GetObjectRequest;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.model.ObjectMetadata;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.model.PutObjectRequest;

import javax.imageio.ImageIO;
import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
import java.io.ByteArrayInputStream;
import java.io.ByteArrayOutputStream;
import java.io.InputStream;
import java.io.IOException;

public class ImageResizerHandler implements RequestHandler<S3Event, Void> {

    private AmazonS3 s3Client = AmazonS3ClientBuilder.defaultClient();

    @Override
    public Void handleRequest(S3Event input, Context context) {
        for (S3Event.NotificationRecord record : input.getRecords()) {
            String bucketName = record.getS3().getBucket().getName();
            String objectKey = record.getS3().getObject().getKey();

            try {
                // Retrieve the image from S3
                InputStream objectData = s3Client.getObject(new GetObjectRequest(bucketName, objectKey)).getObjectContent();

                // Resize the image
                BufferedImage originalImage = ImageIO.read(objectData);
                int thumbWidth = 100;
                int thumbHeight = (int) ((double) thumbWidth / originalImage.getWidth() * originalImage.getHeight());
                BufferedImage thumbnail = new BufferedImage(thumbWidth, thumbHeight, originalImage.getType());
                thumbnail.getGraphics().drawImage(originalImage, 0, 0, thumbWidth, thumbHeight, null);

                // Write the thumbnail to a byte array
                ByteArrayOutputStream os = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
                ImageIO.write(thumbnail, "jpg", os);
                byte[] resizedImageBytes = os.toByteArray();

                // Upload the thumbnail back to S3
                String thumbnailKey = "thumbnails/" + objectKey;
                ObjectMetadata metadata = new ObjectMetadata();
                metadata.setContentLength(resizedImageBytes.length);
                metadata.setContentType("image/jpeg");
                PutObjectRequest putReq = new PutObjectRequest(bucketName, thumbnailKey, new ByteArrayInputStream(resizedImageBytes), metadata);
                s3Client.putObject(putReq);

                context.getLogger().log("Resized image uploaded successfully: " + thumbnailKey);
            } catch (IOException e) {
                context.getLogger().log("Error processing image: " + e.getMessage());
            }
        }
        return null;
    }
}
```

### 3. Deploy the Lambda Function

Package your code into a JAR file and upload it to AWS Lambda. Make sure to set the handler to `com.example.ImageResizerHandler::handleRequest`.

### 4. Configure the S3 Bucket Trigger

Set up your S3 bucket to trigger the Lambda function whenever a new object is uploaded. You can do this in the AWS Management Console by selecting your bucket, going to the Properties tab, and adding an event notification for PUT operations.

### 5. Test the Setup

Upload an image to your S3 bucket and verify that a thumbnail is automatically created and stored in the specified location within the same bucket.

This setup ensures that every time an image is uploaded to the specified S3 bucket, a thumbnail version is generated and stored, leveraging the serverless capabilities of AWS Lambda.
